repnme.cdata!:
Papua New Guinea - Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project for Papua New Guinea were as follows:
            overall outcome was satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the borrower performance was moderately satisfactory.
            There were some important project lessons learned. Firstly,
            the project design was rigorous and realistic in its
            identification of potential risks. It accurately
            pre-identified a number of high risks that surfaced during
            the course of implementation and as such, could be addressed
            by the project team in a timely manner. Among the highest
            risks identified were inadequate or late counterpart
            funding, potential political interference in drawing up
            annual work programs, inability of the government to acquire
            additional land, if required, selection of inappropriate
            contractors, and inability to motivate participating
            communities to comply with contract conditions. The second
            reason for the project's success was that recognizing
            the small size of the civil service in PNG, and the relative
            inexperience with Bank guidelines and procedures, the
            project funded a long term, full time Employer's
            Project Manager to supplement (not supplant) Department of
            Works (DOW) staff numbers and capabilities. Thirdly,
            recognizing the large number of potential risks, the Bank
            project team was proactive in closely supervising the
            project through regular missions and site visits with
            government counterparts to verify implementation progress
            against agreed work plans, the quality of remote works, and
            compliance with safeguards. Fourthly, the socio-economic
            impacts of the project works were systematically monitored
            across beneficiary and control (non-beneficiary) communities
            in all provinces. The results of these surveys were
            presented to DOW and other technical staff during the course
            of the project, highlighting the educational, health and
            local economic development benefits of improved access, and
            also identified some of the negative impacts of the program.

repnme.cdata!:
Papua New Guinea - Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The restructuring of this project is in
            response to the relevant request from the Government of
            Papua New Guinea (GoPNG) and is limited to the extension of
            the project closing date from December 31, 2011 to June 30,
            2012 and reallocation among project categories.
            Implementation progress of the additional financing of Road
            Maintenance and Rehabilitation Project (RMRP) is rated as
            satisfactory, with a disbursement rate of 86 percent (end
            October 2011). All works contracts of RMRP are now
            completed, apart from two significant roads rehabilitation
            contracts which were due to be completed in November 2011,
            but have faced delays and are currently under continuing
            execution. Delays with the remaining contracts were
            primarily due to adverse working conditions (mainly
            extremely adverse weather, which has hindered access to
            construction materials and delayed overall progress) and
            under resourcing of plant, labor and equipment by the key
            contractor of the projects. The performance of the
            implementing agency has been satisfactory and project
            implementation is satisfactory despite often challenging
            circumstances. The construction of a Liquefied Natural Gas
            pipeline and processing facility has taxed the domestic
            contracting capacity and caused fierce competition for
            contractors. The inflationary price environment in PNG has
            also affected contracting capacity. This project
            restructuring would extend project closing date from
            December 31, 2011 to June 30, 2012 with the Regional Vice
            President's approval. The reallocation of amounts among
            categories consists primarily of the formal allocation from
            the 'unallocated' category of the original project
            to rehabilitation of national roads and bridges component.
            Other minor changes reflect the evolved priorities and
            respective financing needs among various project components.

repnme.cdata!:
Papua New Guinea Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary goal of the Road Maintenance
            and Rehabilitation Project is to promote an efficient, safe,
            and reliable roads transport system in the participating
            provinces. Without well-maintained roads, people lack
            sufficient access to markets, which has a direct impact on
            their income. Further, children are more likely to continue
            in school if there is a nearby road, and travel time to
            reach health services decreases meaning better and more
            timely access to treatment.

repnme.cdata!:
Promoting an efficient, safe, and reliable
            roads system for the people of Papua New Guinea

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            promoting an efficient, safe, and reliable roads system for
            the people of Papua New Guinea. The supply and maintenance
            of roads and related infrastructure in the country was
            complicated due to the rugged, mountainous landscape, a
            widely dispersed population, and unconnected road networks.
            Further, the roads sector suffered from inadequate funding,
            land acquisition difficulties, law and order problems, a
            small base of private contractors, and limited private
            sector and community participation. The primary goal of the
            Road Maintenance and Rehabilitation Project funded by World
            Bank was to promote an efficient, safe, and reliable roads
            transport system in the participating provinces. It focused
            on the financing of road maintenance and the rehabilitation
            of national roads and bridges. The project also strengthened
            small and medium sized contractors, and provincial
            administrations, for road maintenance operations. It
            improved the government’s planning and management of the
            roads sector to advance the quality of life for Papua New Guineans.
